review.title: Reinforcement Learning-based Thermal Comfort Control for Vehicle Cabins
review.abstract: Vehicle climate control systems aim to keep passengers thermally comfortable. However, current systems control temperature rather than thermal comfort and tend to be energy hungry, which is of particular concern when considering electric vehicles. This paper poses energy-efficient vehicle comfort control as a Markov Decision Process, which is then solved numerically using Sarsa({\lambda}) and an empirically validated, single-zone, 1D thermal model of the cabin. The resulting controller was tested in simulation using 200 randomly selected scenarios and found to exceed the performance of bang-bang, proportional, simple fuzzy logic, and commercial controllers with 23%, 43%, 40%, 56% increase, respectively. Compared to the next best performing controller, energy consumption is reduced by 13% while the proportion of time spent thermally comfortable is increased by 23%. These results indicate that this is a viable approach that promises to translate into substantial comfort and energy improvements in the car.

metadata.title: Reinforcement Learning-based Thermal Comfort Control for Vehicle Cabins

sections.text: This paper presents an energy-efficient vehicle comfort control as a Markov decision-making process, which is then solved numerically using Sarsa (λ) and an empirically validated, single-zone, 1D thermal model of the cabin. The resulting controller was tested in simulations using 200 randomly selected scenarios and found to exceed the performance of bang-bang, proportional, simple fuzzy logic and commercial controllers by 23%, 43%, 40% and 56% respectively. Compared with the next best controller, energy consumption is reduced by 13%, while the proportion of time spent thermally comfortably is increased by 23%. These results suggest that this is a practicable approach that promises significant improvements in comfort and energy in the car.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: Vehicle HVAC systems (heating, ventilation and air conditioning) aim to ensure that passengers are thermally comfortable. Traditionally, the controllers for these systems are hand-coded and tuned to achieve this goal. However, there are a number of drivers for changes: 1. Current systems only control the cabin temperature, whereas thermal comfort also depends on a variety of other factors (such as radiant heat and airflow). Current systems are energy hungry, whereas electric and hybrid vehicles require a much more energy-efficient approach.

sections.heading: 2. Related work
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 2.1. HVAC control methods in vehicles
sections.text: Much of the work on HVAC control (Stephen et al., 2010; Farzaneh and Tootoonchi, 2008; Atthajariyakul and Leephakpreeda, 2005; Goenka and Maranville, 2013) remains rooted in thermal comfort models developed for home and office environments, with the best-known comfort model being the predictive mean vote (PMV); and personal parameters (such as metabolic rate and clothing) developed based on environmental parameters (such as air temperature, air temperature and relative humidity).

sections.heading: 2.2. Reinforcement learning-based control applications
sections.text: Dalamagkidis et al. (2007) and Fazenda et al. (2014) have investigated the problem of optimizing thermal comfort-based control by using RL-based technology in the context of buildings and not of cars. Dalamagkidis et al. (2007) have developed and simulated a reinforcement based on the use of Matlab / Simulink. The reward is a function of the thermal comfort of the building inhabitants, energy consumption and indoor air quality. The proposed controller was compared to a fuzzy PD controller (an evaluation approach that is also used here) and the results showed that after a few simulated years of training the learning controller performed better than the other two controllers. Dalamagkidis et al. (2007) show a problem with the reinforcement of learning controller-based controller-controller-controller systems that have a sufficient effect.

sections.heading: 3. Materials and methods
sections.text: We formulate the cabin comfort control problem as the Markov Decision Process (MDP) with continuous states defined by the tuple < S, S0, A, T, R, γ >, where S is the (infinite) series of states of the cabin environment from which a series of initial states S0 S is drawn, A is a finite series of measures (e.g. the determination of the blinding door position), T: S × A → S is a deterministic environmental model that maps the states and actions to subsequent states, R: S × A → < is a function that expresses the reward for actions in a particular state, and γ is a discount factor that enables such actions in the future is less valuable than a reward that is immediately achieved. The solution of the MDP is a policy: S → A or the assignment of states to actions, and in particular an optimal solution that maximizes the expected reward.

sections.text: The simulation data were compared with empirical data collected by the authors within different heating and cooling scenarios (described in Hintea et al. (2014)). Figures 3 and 4, based on experiments with a Jaguar XJ in the MIRA LTD climatic wind tunnel, show the heating (by cold) and cooling (by heat) of the vehicle cabin based on headrest height sensors over a series of experiments and also show the simulated or "model results." Simulated results are based on the Bang-Bang controller described further in Section 4.1. These diagrams show that the simulation is broadly consistent with the properties of the physical system and that a controller working well with the simulation is likely to work well in practice as far as temperature control is concerned. Although the modelling of energy consumption is based on reasonable assumptions, we do not have at this stage experimental data that can be validated with the model.

sections.heading: 3.4. Tile coding
sections.text: In contrast to other work, tiles that comprise the combined state and action space do not use a separate function approximator, but a single function approximator. The tile encoding used to represent the action values consisted of 30 tiles, 10 tiles that contain variables (Ta, Tm, To, Ti, vi, Ar) and 20 tiles that contain variables (Ta, Ti, vi, Ar).

sections.heading: 3.5. Action representation
sections.text: The catalogue of measures consists of a vector (vi, Ti, Ar) T in which each component of the vector adopts one of a small group of discrete values. Specifically, there are four possible air flows from the vents vi-1, 34, 67, 100-1. Five possible ventilation temperatures can be selected, which are uniformly defined over the range Ti-A [7, 60] ℃. Finally, three positions of the recirculation valve Ar-A (0, 12, 1) are available. This results in a total of 60 (4 x 5 x 3) possible measures.

sections.heading: 3.6. Reward function
sections.text: The learning objective is to maximize the time spent in comfort (defined here as if the occupant is ET 24 ± 1 ° C) while minimizing energy consumption. This can be expressed as a reward function: R (s, a) = RC (s) − E (s, a) / w (7) RC (s) = {0 if Te 24 ± 1 ° C − 1 otherwise (8) E (s, a) = market value Q-E + 2vi (9), where RC is the penalty for discomfort, E the cost of energy, w = 30,000 the energy weight divisor (which, in layman's terms, means that a 1% improvement in comfort is equivalent to 300 W).This weight can be adjusted to achieve a different balance between energy and comfort (see Section 4.3.1).The above reward function could be expanded further to ensure goals such as minimizing fan noise or ensuring the clarity of the screen are not punished as being outside the limits of the worst component).

sections.heading: 3.7. Meta parameters
sections.text: Meta-parameters control the learning process and can influence how fast the learning progresses. The first is the number of steps per episode set to 500, which allows the agent to achieve a comfortable state from each starting state, but also that the episode length is not so long that new starting states are rarely experienced. The reward discount factor γ = 0.99 ensures that a policy is adequately rewarded for actions that do not produce an immediate reward. As the reward function does not provide a reward for moving toward comfort (but only for reaching it), the setting of almost 1 allows the agent to achieve comfort even at extreme initial temperatures, the learning rate α = 0.01, the exploration factor ε = 0.16 (for the first 190,000 episodes and zero thereafter) and the decay of the eligibility tracks λ = 0.98 were decided by considering performance during the first 2,000 episodes, as discussed in Section 3.1.

sections.heading: 3.8. Evaluation method
sections.text: The performance of the RL controller is tested at regular intervals during learning using a set of 200 randomly selected startup states ST-S0, known as the Test Scenario Set. This approach is a standard test that can be used for all controllers to provide a fair comparison while ensuring that the test for possible startup states is reasonably comprehensive.

sections.heading: 4. Evaluation
sections.text: The RL-based controller is evaluated by comparing its performance with a bang-bang controller, a proportional controller, a commercial controller and a fuzzy logic controller. Three possible Ts temperature sensors are simulated for each controller: the true cabin air temperature (air), the average cabin and interior temperature (average) and the corresponding temperature (et). All controllers operate according to the action representation (see Section 3.5).

sections.heading: 4.1. Bang-bang, proportional and commercial controllers
sections.text: The first three hand-coded controllers are somewhat similar: the Bangbang controller blows the maximum fan rate to cool or heat the cabin until it is within 1 ° C of the target, then blows the minimum fan rate and tries to reach the target temperature; the proportional controller is similar but reduces fan speed exponentially vi = 100 − 99 exp (− | Ts − 24 | 10) as the sensor temperature approaches the target temperature; the commercial controller is based on a commercial specification, which tends to use lower fan rates than the proportional controller, probably to avoid noise and vibration, but is otherwise quite similar.

sections.heading: 4.2. Simple fuzzy logic controller
sections.text: For evaluation, a simple fuzzy logic controller was implemented in Java using the Fuzzylite library version 1.0 (Rada-Vilela, 2014). In addition to the sensor temperature Ts, this controller also receives the internal mass temperature Tm. Fuzzy set functions for input temperatures Ts, Tm are neutral (24 ± 1 ° C), cold (below neutral) and hot (top) with some increased overlaps between the individual ranges. For ventilation temperatures, the rates are low (below 10 ° C), medium (about 20 ° C), high (above 30 ° C) and for ventilation flow rates low (below 30 ° C − 1), medium (about 50 ° C − 1) and high (above 70 ° C − 1) with similarly rapid overlapps.The fuzzy logic rules are summarized in Figure 5. These rules are slightly modified from those of Dalamagkidis et al. (2007) and Kelly and Pawlak (2003).

sections.heading: 4.3. Results
sections.text: The relative performance of the RL controller compared to that of the hand-coded controllers is shown in Table 3. The RL controller provides the largest (least negative) average reward per step, consumes less power and provides more convenience. This performance develops during learning, as shown in Figure 6. The RL controller achieves an average reward of − 1.2 after 200,000 learning phases (about 6.3 simulated years). Learning for the Sarsa (λ) algorithm (implemented in Java) corresponds to 200,000 episodes completed in 85 minutes with a 2.9 GHz Intel ® Core ™ i7 processor. These results result in an average energy saving of 37% compared to the test scenarios established compared to the simple, fuzzy-logic-based controller, while thermal comfort was achieved and successfully maintained. Figure 7 shows how each controller controls the occupant ET in a cooling scenario (45 ° C cabin temperature, 45 ° C air intake and some block temperature is caused by blocking air).

sections.heading: 4.3.1. Effect of parameter choices
sections.text: For example, Figure 8 shows how the mean reward changes with the learning rate α over the episodes 1000-2000 000 and that a rate of 0.01 produces the fastest learning. Similar experiments show the best values for λ (0.98) and ε (0.16). Although these parameter selections are suitable in early learning stages, other values may be better later on. In particular, the reward performance improves considerably when exploration is turned off in later learning stages. The black line drawn in the diagram corresponds to the target curve (or Pareto optimal front) and shows a progressive change in the balance between comfort and energy as the energy divisor values are increased in terms of energy consumption and percentage comfort.

sections.heading: 5. Discussion
sections.text: Firstly, not all factors relevant to thermal comfort are simulated or included in the ET comfort measurement, such as humidity, clothing level or metabolic work rate of the subject. If a particular thermal comfort model leads to sub-optimal comfort when implemented as a control, this implies that there may be a problem with the comfort model, as it also helps to detect window fogging and thus include a penalty for fogging in the reward function. Given the diversity of opinions on comfort models and the relative importance of parameters in the literature, this iterative approach seems to be best. Secondly, the hand-coded controls presented in this paper may imply a problem with the comfort model and thus help to identify which parameter or feature is missing.

sections.heading: 5.1. Pathway to implementation in the car
sections.text: The occupant ET, which is used here as a proxy for comfort, cannot be measured directly in a real vehicle cabin, and the need for a proxy inspired the development of a Virtual Thermal Comfort Sensor (VTCS) (Hintea et al., 2013). VTCS uses a distributed set of sensors to estimate comfort based on a machine learning approach. Note that all learning takes place offline and therefore little calculation is required to implement the VTCS approach in the car. In principle, VTCS can be used to estimate comfort for different zones such as the upper and lower body as well as different passenger positions. An important consideration when designing a controller is the accuracy of the sensor. No matter how good the controller is, inaccurate measurements lead to incorrect control. The VTCS approach has the added advantage of making it possible to integrate a range of cost-effective sensors rather than relying on a single sensor.

sections.heading: 6. Conclusions and future work
sections.text: Our results show that the RL-based controller offers better comfort (67% time in comfort versus 55% for the Bang-Bang controller with averaged sensor) and is more efficient (0.77 kW for the RL controller versus 0.88 kW for the Bang-Bang controller). Note that the exact level of energy consumption differs from this in practice because the energy consumption aspect of the simulation has not been fully validated. The performance of the RL controller is noteworthy for two reasons: first, the reward function is not "coach" of the solution; the reward occurs only when comfort is attained; second, the RL controller is not explicitly informed about the current ET, but manages to control it in a stable manner.

A learning episode begins by selecting an initial state at random from the distribution s0 ∼ S0 and then continues with the agent selecting an action and the cabin model returning a new state and reward until a maximum number of steps is reached. For some problems, it is possible to have a terminal state that ends the episode. However, this is not possible here, since the reaching comfort is not sufficient; the agent needs to efficiently maintain comfort as well. The initial state distribution should be comprehensive to avoid leaving parts of the state space unexplored. The agent is ε-greedy, which means that with probability ε it selects a random action and otherwise it selects according to the largest estimated utility for that state, as per (2). Although it might be possible to implement a learning system directly in the car, prior works in this domain (such as, Ng et al. (2006)) suggest learning in simulation first.

metadata.abstractText: Vehicle climate control systems aim to keep passengers thermally comfortable. However, current systems control temperature rather than thermal comfort and tend to be energy hungry, which is of particular concern when considering electric vehicles. This paper poses energy-efficient vehicle comfort control as a Markov Decision Process, which is then solved numerically using Sarsa(λ) and an empirically validated, single-zone, 1D thermal model of the cabin. The resulting controller was tested in simulation using 200 randomly selected scenarios and found to exceed the performance of bang-bang, proportional, simple fuzzy logic, and commercial controllers with 23%, 43%, 40%, 56% increase, respectively. Compared to the next best performing controller, energy consumption is reduced by 13% while the proportion of time spent thermally comfortable is increased by 23%. These results indicate that this is a viable approach that promises to translate into substantial comfort and energy improvements in the car.
